citations.narrative:
Five adult red kangaroos are housed in an outdoor primary enclosure that has no perimeter fence. The primary enclosure
is made of a 6 foot high chain link fence. There is a row of conifer trees planted around this fence. Beyond the conifers,
approximate 3 to 4 feet outside the primary enclosure fence, there are some approximately 4 foot tall posts that were
used to support two strands of electric fence wire. The electric fence is not in use. There are two stands of wire on only
two sides of the enclosure and no wire on the other two sides. The inspector reminded the licensee that a two strand
electric fence outside the primary enclosure does not meet the requirement for a 6 foot high perimeter fence surrounding
the primary enclosure. The licensee said he had tried using the electric fence inside the 6 foot chain link fence, but the
kangaroos had gotten entangled in it.
All outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient
height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals,
such as, but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and
elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter
fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the
Administrator. The facility must have a perimeter fence appropriate for the species being housed, 6 feet high, or have an
approved variance by the Administrator.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Five adult red kangaroos are housed in an outdoor primary enclosure that has no perimeter fence. The primary enclosure 
is made of a 6 foot high chain link fence. There is a row of conifer trees planted around this fence. Beyond the conifers, 
approximate 3 to 4 feet outside the primary enclosure fence, there are some approximately 4 foot tall posts that were 
used to support two strands of electric fence wire. The electric fence is not in use. There are two stands of wire on only 
two sides of the enclosure and no wire on the other two sides. The inspector reminded the licensee that a two strand 
electric fence outside the primary enclosure does not meet the requirement for a 6 foot high perimeter fence surrounding 
the primary enclosure. The licensee said he had tried using the electric fence inside the 6 foot chain link fence, but the 
kangaroos had gotten entangled in it.  
All outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient 
height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals, 
such as, but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and 
elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be 
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going 
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary 
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter 
fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the 
Administrator. The facility must have a perimeter fence appropriate for the species being housed, 6 feet high, or have an 
approved variance by the Administrator. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
